issue.title: deque and vector pop_back don't specify iterator invalidation requirements

discussion.p: I think it's obvious that vector::pop_back invalidates the path-the-end iterator, but I cannot find language that says so to my satisfaction in the Standard. N3797 Table 101 lists a.pop_back() semantics as "Destroys the last element", but nowhere do I see this required to invalidate the end iterator (or iterators previously referring to the last element). /11 states "Unless otherwise specified (either explicitly or by defining a function in terms of other functions), invoking a container member function or passing a container as an argument to a library function shall not invalidate iterators to, or change the values of, objects within that container." /3 says that each flavor of vector::erase "Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the erase", but pop_back isn't discussed, and it wasn't specified in terms of erase.

Similarly for std::deque, Table 101 and /11 both apply. Yet likewise doesn't discuss pop_back nor pop_front. Furthermore paragraph 4 fails to specify the iterator-invalidation guarantees when erasing the first element but not the last.
Both std::vector and std::deque are in contrast to std::list, which says in /3 regarding pop_back (as well as all forms of erase, pop_front, and clear) "Effects: Invalidates only the iterators and references to the erased elements."

I believe this reflects our preferred form discussed earlier, specifically putting the signatures with the erase signatures, so that the full specification of erase() applies to the pop_xxx() functions. This covers the case for deque where pop_front() erases the only element (which is both the first and last element).
Open question: the "erase" wording talks about "An erase operation" — are pop_front and pop_back clearly covered by "erase operations"? I believe so, as /1 and other places talk about "insert and erase operations" which covers push/pop functions too. I've added a note which could be used to clarify that if desired.

blockquote.p: This wording is relative to N3936.

blockquote.pre: iterator erase(const_iterator position); iterator erase(const_iterator first, const_iterator last);

blockquote.p:
-4- Effects: An erase operation that erases the last element of a deque invalidates only the past-the-end iterator and all iterators and references to the erased elements. An erase operation that erases the first element of a deque but not the last element invalidates only iterators and references to the erased elements. An erase operation that erases neither the first element nor the last element of a deque invalidates the past-the-end iterator and all iterators and references to all the elements of the deque.
-5- […]
-6- […]

p.ins: -?- Effects: pop_front invalidates iterators and references to the first element of the deque. pop_back invalidates the past-the-end iterator, and all iterators and references to the last element of the deque.
-?- Effects: Invalidates the past-the-end iterator, and iterators and references to the last element of the vector.

discussion.p:
Tony van Eerd: Would be good to define "an erase operation is ..." somewhere.
AM: The containers clause is known to be suboptimal in many ways.
Looks good

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N3936.

blockquote.p: -4- Effects: An erase operation that erases the last element of a deque invalidates only the past-the-end iterator and all iterators and references to the erased elements. An erase operation that erases the first element of a deque but not the last element invalidates only iterators and references to the erased elements. An erase operation that erases neither the first element nor the last element of a deque invalidates the past-the-end iterator and all iterators and references to all the elements of the deque. [Note: pop_front and pop_back are erase operations — end note]
-3- Effects: Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the erase.
